article.headline: Arkansas 71, UMKC 61
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Arkansas coach Stan Heath was looking forward to coming home and playing in front of a friendly environment after four tough road games. For the first 20 minutes Saturday against Missouri-Kansas City, Heath probably wished he and the Razorbacks had stayed on the road. Arkansas (7-1) looked sluggish and lethargic in the first half, as the effects of Thursdays 22-point road loss to Missouri seemed to follow the Razorbacks home. The Razorbacks trailed UMKC by 11 twice in the opening half. But Heath put it to his team at halftime, with Arkansas trailing 31-28, and the Razorbacks responded with a 71-61 victory that was much closer and tougher than the final margin would indicate. "The first half we werent playing with intensity or energy," Heath said. "At halftime I challenged them to play like we needed to play. We hadnt played at home in a while and we needed to pick ourselves up. We did so in the second half." Darian Townes apparently paid close attention to Heath in the locker room at the half. The 6-foot-10 junior dominated the second half, en route to season highs in points (19) and rebounds (8). He helped turn the 3-point halftime deficit into an early second half lead by fueling a 13-5 Arkansas run in the first five minutes after intermission. "We started out slow," Townes said. "(Heath) said to just keep our heads up. We kept our heads and our composure and found a way to win the game. We beat them up inside and got a lot of offensive rebounds." Townes teamed with Charles Thomas, who finished with 16 points, to exploit holes in UMKCs zone defense and allow the Razorbacks to take control. Although never able to really put the Kangaroos away, the Razorbacks never trailed after freshman guard Patrick Beverley hit a driving layup early in the second half. But the Kangaroos (3-5) generally held off Arkansas inside scoring while guards Quintin Day and Dominique Johnson kept UMKC in the game with clutch shooting. Day finished with 14 points, Johnson with 11. "I thought we were better on offense than defense today," UMKC coach Rick Zvosec said. "We started shaky in the second half, but we absorbed the blow and kept going." Gary Ervin, normally a starter for the Razorbacks at point guard, instead came off the bench Saturday to give Arkansas some much-needed offense down the stretch with a big bucket and two key free throws. Sean McCurdy started in place of Ervin and played steady with five assists. For most of the second half, Heath had three guards on the court -- Beverley, Ervin and McCurdy. Ervin said he enjoyed playing at the same time as McCurdy. "I think we did a good job today. We practiced a lot and both did a good job with the tempos and knocking down the shot," he said. Arkansas got a huge lift from reserve Preston Cranford, who was sent in after Sonny Weems had committed four turnovers without scoring. Cranford hit two crucial 3-pointers midway through the second half that held off UMKC. "We needed that," Heath said. "Preston Cranford gave us some very valuable minutes. I keep telling them (reserves) to stay ready and that your time will come. Preston was ready today."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
